quotes.text: He who learns must suffer.
quotes.author: Aeschylus

quotes.text: Words are the physicians of a mind diseased.
quotes.author: Aeschylus

quotes.text: Time waxing old can many a lesson teach.
quotes.author: Aeschylus

quotes.text: For somehow this is tyranny's disease, to trust no friends.
quotes.author: Aeschylus

quotes.text: The guardian of poor suffering mankind.
quotes.author: Aeschylus

quotes.text: Heaven cannot brook two suns nor earth two masters.
quotes.author: Alexander the Great

quotes.text: In everything a portion of everything.
quotes.author: Anaxagoras

quotes.text: Give me a place to stand and I will move the earth.
quotes.author: Archimedes

quotes.text: Eureka! I have found it!
quotes.author: Archimedes

quotes.text: Hope is a waking dream.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: The virtues come about in us neither by nature nor apart from nature
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: The person of moral stature is the one to whom things appear as they truly are
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: Courage is always for the sake of the beautiful
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: One swallow does not make a summer.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: Happiness depends upon ourselves.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: Virtue is a habit of the soul.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: A friend to all is a friend to none.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: Friendship is a single soul dwelling in two bodies.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: Nature does nothing in vain.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: Man is by nature a political animal.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: The law is reason free from passion.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: I found Rome brick, left it marble.
quotes.author: Augustus

quotes.text: Make haste slowly.
quotes.author: Augustus

quotes.text: Truth is the daughter of time.
quotes.author: Aulus Gellius

quotes.text: Let them hate, so long as they fear.
quotes.author: Caligula

quotes.text: Wise men profit more from fools than fools from wise men.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder

quotes.text: Buy the farm outright and cultivate it.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder

quotes.text: The seller must be a seller, not a buyer.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder

quotes.text: Lighter is the wound foreseen.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder
quotes.attribution: Fragments, via Aulus Gellius, Noctes Atticae ~180 CE

quotes.text: Grasp the subject, the words will follow.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder
quotes.attribution: On Oratory, via Julius Victor, Ars Rhetorica ~4th c. CE (Rem tene, verba sequentur)

quotes.text: It is a hard matter to save a city where fish costs more than oxen.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder
quotes.attribution: via Aulus Gellius, Noctes Atticae ~180 CE

quotes.text: Thieves of private property in chains; public in riches.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder

quotes.text: Even with a sword hanging over his head, a Roman speaks out.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder

quotes.text: The best armor is to keep out of range.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder

quotes.text: After I'm dead, let people ask why no statue.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder
quotes.attribution: via Plutarch, Lives ~100 CE (Post mortem, cur non statuam?)

quotes.text: Anger so clouds the mind that it cannot perceive the truth.
quotes.author: Cato the Elder

quotes.text: And for ever, my brother, hail and farewell!.
quotes.author: Catullus

quotes.text: A friend is a second self.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Amicitia, sec. 21 ~44 BCE (Amicus est tamquam alter idem)

quotes.text: The man who backbites an absent friend... is a traitor.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: The shifts of fortune test the reliability of friends.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: The greatest pleasures are only narrowly separated from disgust.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Finibus, Book I, sec. 37 ~45 BCE

quotes.text: The wise are instructed by reason.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Finibus, Book IV, sec. 18 ~45 BCE (Sapientes ratione instruuntur)

quotes.text: The beginnings of all things are small.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Finibus, Book V, sec. 58 ~45 BCE

quotes.text: Justice is the set and constant purpose which gives to every man his due.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Legibus, Book I, sec. 19 ~52 BCE

quotes.text: Let the punishment match the offense.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Legibus, Book I, sec. 42 ~52 BCE (Poena ad maleficium accomodanda)

quotes.text: The good of the people is the highest law.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Legibus, Book III, sec. 8 ~52 BCE (Salus populi suprema lex esto)

quotes.text: The authority of those who teach is often an obstacle to learning.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Natura Deorum, Book I, sec. 10 ~45 BCE

quotes.text: The function of wisdom is to discriminate between good and evil.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 153 ~44 BCE

quotes.text: Justice is the crowning glory of the virtues.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 20 ~44 BCE (Iustitia est virtutum regina)

quotes.text: The foundation of justice is good faith.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 23 ~44 BCE

quotes.text: The more laws, the less justice.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 33 ~44 BCE (Quo plurimae leges, ibi plurimae iniuriae)

quotes.text: The greatest victories are won without bloodshed.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 35 ~44 BCE

quotes.text: We must not only have the right principles, but also the right practice.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 4 ~44 BCE

quotes.text: The first bond of society is marriage.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 54 ~44 BCE

quotes.text: The first duty of a man is to defend his country.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 57 ~44 BCE

quotes.text: Let arms yield to the toga.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Officiis, Book I, sec. 77 ~44 BCE (Cedant arma togae)

quotes.text: Memory is the treasury and guardian of all things.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Oratore, Book I, sec. 18 ~55 BCE

quotes.text: No one can speak well unless he thoroughly understands his subject.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Oratore, Book II, sec. 114 ~55 BCE

quotes.text: History is the witness of the times.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Oratore, Book II, sec. 36 ~55 BCE

quotes.text: The face is the image of the soul.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: De Oratore, Book III, sec. 221 ~55 BCE

quotes.text: The harvest of old age is the memory and rich store of blessings.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Old men are children a second time.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Old age is the crown of life, our play's last act.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: While there's life, there's hope.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Epistulae ad Atticum, Book IX, 10 ~49 BCE (Dum anima est, spes esse dicitur)

quotes.text: The causes of events are ever more interesting than the events themselves.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Epistulae ad Familiares, Book V, 12 ~46 BCE

quotes.text: The arrogance of officialdom should be tempered and controlled.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Nothing is so fortified that it cannot be taken with money.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: To be ignorant of what occurred before you were born is to remain always a child.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Freedom is participation in power.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Philippicae, II, sec. 113 ~44 BCE (Libertas est potestas in sua re publica)

quotes.text: A nation can survive its fools, and even the ambitious.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Philippicae, III, sec. 1 ~44 BCE (Continues 'but it cannot survive treason from within')

quotes.text: The life given us by nature is short, but the memory of a life well spent is eternal.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: The life of the dead is placed in the memory of the living.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: The budget should be balanced.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Philippicae, V, sec. 11 ~44 BCE (Oportet esse rationes certas)

quotes.text: Endless money forms the sinews of war.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Philippicae, V, sec. 5 ~44 BCE (Nervos belli, pecuniam infinitam)

quotes.text: The evil implanted in man by nature spreads so imperceptibly.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: The pursuit of knowledge is the most noble occupation of man.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: We are slaves of the law so that we may be free.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Nothing is so unbelievable that oratory cannot make it acceptable.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Laws are silent in times of war.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Pro Milone, sec. 11 ~52 BCE (Silent enim leges inter arma)

quotes.text: There is no quality I would rather have than gratitude.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: The wise man is never surprised by the changes of fortune.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Tusculanae Disputationes, Book III, sec. 30 ~45 BCE

quotes.text: Confidence is that feeling by which the mind embarks in great things.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Tusculanae Disputationes, Book IV, sec. 80 ~45 BCE

quotes.text: A happy life consists in tranquility of mind.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.attribution: Tusculanae Disputationes, Book V, sec. 1 ~45 BCE

quotes.text: Greed is but a word jealous men inflict upon the ambitious.
quotes.author: Crassus

quotes.text: No man was rich who could not maintain a legion upon his annual income.
quotes.author: Crassus

quotes.text: By convention sweet, by convention bitter.
quotes.author: Democritus

quotes.text: The senses accuse the mind.
quotes.author: Democritus

quotes.text: No man can tell what the future may bring forth.
quotes.author: Demosthenes

quotes.text: Delivery, delivery, delivery.
quotes.author: Demosthenes

quotes.text: Every advantage in the past is judged in the light of the final issue.
quotes.author: Demosthenes

quotes.text: Whatever shall be to the advantage of all, may that prevail!
quotes.author: Demosthenes

quotes.text: The easiest thing in the world is self-deceit.
quotes.author: Demosthenes

quotes.text: I am a citizen of the world.
quotes.author: Diogenes
quotes.attribution: via Diogenes Laërtius, Lives 3rd c. CE

quotes.text: No one is ever hurt but by himself.
quotes.author: Diogenes
quotes.attribution: via Diogenes Laërtius, Lives 3rd c. CE

quotes.text: The foundation of every state is the education of its youth.
quotes.author: Diogenes
quotes.attribution: via Diogenes Laërtius, Lives 3rd c. CE

quotes.text: By earth we see earth, by water water.
quotes.author: Empedocles

quotes.text: Difficulties show men what they are.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: No great thing is created suddenly.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: No man is free who is not master of himself.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Wealth consists not in having great possessions.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: We have two ears and one mouth so we may listen more.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Appearances to the mind are of four kinds.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Don't explain your philosophy. Embody it.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: The greater the difficulty, the more glory in surmounting it.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Freedom is the right to live as we wish.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Only the educated are free.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Preconceptions must be overturned one by one.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Freedom is secured not by fulfilling desires.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Attach yourself to what is good for the soul.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Every habit and faculty is confirmed by acts.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Know first who you are, then adorn yourself.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: It takes more than a good body to be a good man.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Other people's views and troubles can be contagious.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: The key is to keep company with those who uplift.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: You become what you give your attention to.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: First say what you would be; then do what you must.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Keep your attention focused entirely on the present.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Small-minded people blame others.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Neither the body nor wealth belong to you.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Practice yourself, for heaven's sake, in little things.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: The world turns aside to let him pass who knows where he is going.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Wealth does not bring excellence, but excellence brings wealth.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Make the mind your fortress.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: There is only one way to happiness: cease worrying.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If you wish to be a writer, write.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Any person capable of angering you becomes your master.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: It's not what happens to you, but how you react that matters.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Man is troubled not by events but by the meaning he gives them.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Make the best use of what is in your power.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: The essence of good is in your power.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Bear and forbear.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If evil be said of you, and if it be true, correct yourself.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: When offended, turn to yourself and see your own faults.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Men are disturbed not by things, but by views.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Seek not that events should happen as you will.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: All philosophy lies in two words: sustain and abstain.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: He is a wise man who does not grieve for what he has not.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Control thy passions lest they take vengeance.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Be careful to leave your sons well instructed rather than rich.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: It is impossible to live pleasantly without living wisely.
quotes.author: Epicurus

quotes.text: Of all the things wisdom provides for happiness the greatest is friendship.
quotes.author: Epicurus

quotes.text: Leave no stone unturned.
quotes.author: Euripides

quotes.text: Friends show their love in times of trouble not happiness.
quotes.author: Euripides

quotes.text: One loyal friend is worth ten thousand relatives.
quotes.author: Euripides

quotes.text: Hail, Emperor, those about to die salute you.
quotes.author: Gladiators

quotes.text: The road up and down is one and the same.
quotes.author: Heraclitus

quotes.text: You cannot step twice into the same rivers.
quotes.author: Heraclitus

quotes.text: Men trust their ears less than their eyes.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Circumstances rule men; men do not rule circumstances.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Haste in every business brings failures.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Great deeds are usually wrought at great risks.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Force has no place where there is need of skill.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Call no man happy until he is dead.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The most odious of all things is ingratitude.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The gods do not allow the same man to triumph forever.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Many men prefer to die rather than think.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The only good is knowledge, and the only evil is ignorance.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: A man’s character is his fate.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Great wealth without wisdom is a dangerous thing.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Time is the wisest of all things that are.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: From great empires come great ruins.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: A man who does not speak will not be understood.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: In peace, sons bury their fathers; in war, fathers bury sons.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Egypt is the gift of the Nile.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: No one is so foolish as to prefer war to peace.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Custom is king of all.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The king’s misfortune was that he had no one to tell him the truth.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: It is better to be envied than pitied.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: It is the nature of tyranny to mistrust everyone.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The destiny of men is to be ruled by their passions.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The most perfect happiness is to live in a well-governed state.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The most hateful human misfortune is for a wise man to have no influence.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Adversity reveals the genius of a general; good fortune conceals it.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Fortune is like a woman: if you treat her gently, she will be kind.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: No one ever stops a war because he has won too much.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The gods will not suffer anyone to think himself equal to them.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The only real evil is to be a slave to fear.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Those who trust in fortune are like men who build on sand.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Freedom is the most precious possession.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Men are at the mercy of events, not events at the mercy of men.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: It is better by noble boldness to run the risk of being defeated.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Success is the child of audacity.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Success often depends on small things.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The gods love to interrupt our plans.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Soft lands breed soft men.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Knowledge without action is useless.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The bitterest pain among men: to have much knowledge but no power.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: The worst pain a man can suffer: to have insight into much and power over nothing.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Very few things happen at the right time, and the rest do not happen at all.
quotes.author: Herodotus

quotes.text: Everything in excess is opposed to nature.
quotes.author: Hippocrates

quotes.text: Life is short the art long.
quotes.author: Hippocrates

quotes.text: Natural forces within us are the true healers of disease.
quotes.author: Hippocrates

quotes.text: Make a habit of two things: to help or at least to do no harm.
quotes.author: Hippocrates

quotes.text: If any man obeys the gods, they listen to him also.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: But the gods give to mortals not everything at the same time.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: Think not to match yourself against gods
quotes.author: Homer
quotes.attribution: Iliad Book V, lines 440-442 ~750 BCE. Continues ", for men that walk the earth cannot hold their own with the immortals."

quotes.text: When a Man's exhausted, wine will build his strength.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: Victory passes back and forth between men.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: And some day let them say of him: 'He is better by far than his father.'
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: And fate? No one alive has ever escaped it, neither brave man nor coward
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: For a friend with an understanding heart is worth no less than a brother.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: Words empty as the wind are best left unsaid.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: It is the god who accomplishes all things.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: The proof of battle is action, proof of words, debate.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: But the will of Zeus will always overpower the will of men.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: Once a thing has been done, the fool sees it.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: The Fates have given mortals hearts that can endure.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: There is a time for many words and there is also a time for sleep.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: Never despair.
quotes.author: Horace
quotes.attribution: Odes, Book I, ode vii, line 27 ~23 BCE

quotes.text: Seize the day.
quotes.author: Horace
quotes.attribution: Odes, Book I, ode xi ~23 BCE

quotes.text: I have built a monument more lasting than bronze.
quotes.author: Horace
quotes.attribution: Odes, Book III, ode xxx, line 1 ~23 BCE

quotes.text: We are dust and shadow.
quotes.author: Horace
quotes.attribution: Odes, Book IV, ode vii, line 16 ~23 BCE

quotes.text: Experience is the teacher of all things.
quotes.author: Julius Caesar
quotes.attribution: Commentarii de Bello Civili, Book II, Ch. 8 ~45 BCE (Usus magister est rerum omnium.)

quotes.text: Fortune can bring about great changes.
quotes.author: Julius Caesar
quotes.attribution: Commentarii de Bello Civili, Book III, Ch. 68 ~45 BCE (Sed fortuna, quae plurimum potest... Continues 'in every affair and especially in war, can bring about great changes in a moment of time.')

quotes.text: Men willingly believe what they wish.
quotes.author: Julius Caesar
quotes.attribution: Commentarii de Bello Gallico, Book III, Ch. 18 ~50 BCE (Fere libenter homines id quod volunt credunt.)

quotes.text: I came, I saw, I conquered.
quotes.author: Julius Caesar
quotes.attribution: Letter to Roman Senate ~47 BCE (Veni vidi vici)

quotes.text: The die is cast.
quotes.author: Julius Caesar
quotes.attribution: Suetonius, Lives ~121 CE (Alea iacta est; mostly accepted)

quotes.text: It is difficult not to write satire.
quotes.author: Juvenal

quotes.text: Honesty is praised and left to shiver.
quotes.author: Juvenal

quotes.text: Censure acquits the raven, but pursues the dove.
quotes.author: Juvenal

quotes.text: No one ever suddenly became depraved.
quotes.author: Juvenal

quotes.text: Unhappy poverty has nothing in it harder to bear than that it makes men ridiculous.
quotes.author: Juvenal

quotes.text: Adversity tries men, prosperity corrupts them.
quotes.author: Livy

quotes.text: We fear things in proportion to our ignorance of them.
quotes.author: Livy

quotes.text: Men are only too clever at shifting blame from their own shoulders.
quotes.author: Livy

quotes.text: Fortune blinds the eyes of the wise.
quotes.author: Livy

quotes.text: The result justifies the deed.
quotes.author: Livy

quotes.text: Shared danger is the strongest of bonds.
quotes.author: Livy
quotes.attribution: Ab Urbe Condita, Book II sec. 39 ~27 BCE

quotes.text: From abundance springs satiety.
quotes.author: Livy
quotes.attribution: Ab Urbe Condita, Book III sec. 1 ~27 BCE

quotes.text: Better late than never.
quotes.author: Livy
quotes.attribution: Ab Urbe Condita, Book IV sec. 2 ~27 BCE

quotes.text: Woe to the vanquished!
quotes.author: Livy
quotes.attribution: Ab Urbe Condita, Book V sec. 48 ~27 BCE

quotes.text: We can endure neither our vices nor the remedies for them.
quotes.author: Livy
quotes.attribution: Ab Urbe Condita, Praefatio sec. 9 ~27 BCE

quotes.text: Delay is ever fatal to those who are prepared.
quotes.author: Lucan

quotes.text: The victorious cause pleased the gods, but the vanquished pleased Cato.
quotes.author: Lucan

quotes.text: Idle rumors are proof enough for fools.
quotes.author: Lucan

quotes.text: By boldness great fears are concealed.
quotes.author: Lucan

quotes.text: Poverty, the mother of manhood.
quotes.author: Lucan

quotes.text: Nothing can be created out of nothing.
quotes.author: Lucretius
quotes.attribution: De Rerum Natura, Book I lines 156–157 ~60 BC

quotes.text: Life is one long struggle in the dark.
quotes.author: Lucretius
quotes.attribution: De Rerum Natura, Book II line 54 ~60 BC

quotes.text: All things fade and quickly turn to myth.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Be tolerant with others and strict with yourself.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Confine yourself to the present.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Death smiles at us all; all we can do is smile back.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Life is neither good nor evil but only a place for good and evil.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Loss is nothing else but change.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Reject your sense of injury and the injury itself disappears.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Remember that very little is needed to make a happy life.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The art of living is more like wrestling than dancing.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The best revenge is not to be like your enemy.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The soul becomes dyed with the color of its thoughts.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Waste no more time arguing what a good man should be. Be one.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: You always own the option of having no opinion.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The wise man regards the reason for all his actions.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: How ridiculous and how strange to be surprised at anything.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: If it is not right, do not do it; if it is not true, do not say it.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Look back over the past, with its changing empires that rose and fell.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Begin each day by saying: I shall meet the meddler, the ungrateful, the arrogant.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: When you arise in the morning think of what a privilege it is to be alive.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The first rule is to keep an untroubled spirit.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Do every act of your life as if it were your last.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Nothing has such power to broaden the mind as the ability to investigate.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbor says.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The memory of everything is very soon overwhelmed in time.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Time is a sort of river of passing events.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Nothing happens to any man that he is not formed by nature to bear.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Remember: Matter. How tiny your share of it.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Observe constantly that all things take place by change.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: A man's worth is no greater than his ambitions.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Look within. Let neither the peculiar quality of anything nor its value escape you.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Adapt yourself to the things among which your lot has been cast.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Whatever anyone does or says, I must be good.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Think of the life you have lived until now as over.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Never let the future disturb you.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Stick to what’s in front of you—idea, action, utterance.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Here is a rule to remember in future: when anything tempts you to feel bitter.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: You have power over your mind—not outside events.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Be content to seem what you really are.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: My poems are naughty, but my life is pure.
quotes.author: Martial

quotes.text: Laugh if you are wise.
quotes.author: Martial

quotes.text: Life is not living, but living in health.
quotes.author: Martial

quotes.text: Fortune and love favor the brave.
quotes.author: Ovid

quotes.text: In our play we reveal what kind of people we are.
quotes.author: Ovid

quotes.text: Nothing is stronger than habit.
quotes.author: Ovid

quotes.text: Take rest; a field that has rested gives a beautiful crop.
quotes.author: Ovid

quotes.text: The cause is hidden. The effect is visible to all.
quotes.author: Ovid

quotes.text: What is, is, and cannot not be.
quotes.author: Parmenides

quotes.text: You cannot know what is not.
quotes.author: Parmenides

quotes.text: Words have a longer life than deeds.
quotes.author: Pindar

quotes.text: The test of any man lies in action.
quotes.author: Pindar

quotes.text: Water is best.
quotes.author: Pindar

quotes.text: Become who you are.
quotes.author: Pindar

quotes.text: O my soul, do not aspire to immortal life, but exhaust the limits of the possible.
quotes.author: Pindar

quotes.text: The curse of ignorance is that the ignorant do not know they are ignorant.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: A good decision is based on knowledge not on numbers.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Courage is knowing what not to fear.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Good actions give strength to ourselves and inspire good actions in others.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The first and greatest victory is to conquer yourself.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Knowledge becomes evil if the aim be not virtuous.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The soul takes nothing with her to the next world but her education.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: False words are not only evil in themselves, but they infect the soul.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Human behavior flows from three main sources: desire, emotion, and knowledge.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: We are twice armed if we fight with faith.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Wise men speak because they have something to say.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Knowledge is the food of the soul.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Excellence is not a gift but a skill that takes practice.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Knowledge acquired under compulsion has no hold.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The beginning is the most important part of the work.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The heaviest penalty for declining to rule is to be ruled by someone inferior.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Necessity is the mother of invention.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Those who tell the stories rule society.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Music is a moral law.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Justice means minding one’s own business.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Opinion is the medium between knowledge and ignorance.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The empty vessel makes the loudest sound.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The price good men pay for indifference to public affairs is to be ruled by evil men.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Ideas are the source of all things.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Astronomy compels the soul to look upwards.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Democracy passes into despotism.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Poetry is nearer to vital truth than history.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: At the touch of love everyone becomes a poet.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: The god of love lives in a state of need.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Beauty is the splendor of truth.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Thinking is the talking of the soul with itself.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: Wonder is the feeling of the philosopher.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.text: No man is wise enough by himself.
quotes.author: Plautus

quotes.text: Patience is the best remedy for every trouble.
quotes.author: Plautus

quotes.text: Where there are friends there is wealth.
quotes.author: Plautus

quotes.text: The only certainty is that nothing is certain.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book II, Ch. 5 ~77 CE (Nil certi nisi quod nihil certum)

quotes.text: Grief has limits, whereas apprehension has none.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book VII, Ch. 1 ~77 CE

quotes.text: How many things are judged impossible before they occur.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book VII, Ch. 1 ~77 CE (Quam multa fieri non posse priusquam sint facta indicantur)

quotes.text: Nature has given man no better thing than shortness of life.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book VII, Ch. 189 ~77 CE

quotes.text: Man is the only one that knows nothing without being taught.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book VII, Ch. 2 ~77 CE

quotes.text: In wine there is truth.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book XIV, Ch. 141 ~77 CE (In vino veritas)

quotes.text: The best plan is to profit by the folly of others.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book XVIII, Ch. 31 ~77 CE

quotes.text: Such is the audacity of man, that he hath learned to counterfeit Nature.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: Natural History, Book XXXVI, Ch. 179 ~77 CE

quotes.text: True glory: do what deserves to be written, write what deserves to be read.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder

quotes.text: Fortune favors the brave.
quotes.author: Pliny the Elder
quotes.attribution: via Pliny the Younger, Letters ~100 CE (Fortes fortuna iuvat)

quotes.text: Prosperity is no just scale; adversity is the only balance to weigh friends.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: Learn to be pleased with little.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: It is not histories I am writing, but lives.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: The whole life of man is but a point of time; let us enjoy it.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: A few vices are sufficient to darken many virtues.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Life of Cato the Elder ~100 CE

quotes.text: Nothing is cheap that is superfluous.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Life of Cato the Elder ~100 CE

quotes.text: We ought not to treat living creatures like shoes.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Life of Cato the Elder ~100 CE

quotes.text: Men’s minds are more easily moved by what they see than by what they hear.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: Courage stands halfway between cowardice and rashness.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: It is part of a good man to do great and noble deeds, though he risk everything.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: No man ever wetted clay and then left it, as if there would be bricks by the morrow.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: Time is the wisest of all counselors.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: Perseverance is more prevailing than violence.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: An imbalance between rich and poor is the oldest and most fatal ailment of republics.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: The measure of a man is the way he bears up under misfortune.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: Character is simply habit long continued.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: To find fault is easy; to do better may be difficult.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: What we achieve inwardly will change outer reality.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: I don't need a friend who changes when I change.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: Know how to listen, and you will profit even from those who talk badly.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: The mind is not a vessel to be filled, but a fire to be kindled.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Moralia, On Listening to Lectures ~100 CE

quotes.text: Silence at the proper season is wisdom.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: Character is long-standing habit.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Moralia, On the Education of Children ~100 CE

quotes.text: Medicine to produce health must know disease.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Moralia, On the Education of Children ~100 CE

quotes.text: The drop hollows the stone not by force but by falling often.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Moralia, On the Education of Children ~100 CE

quotes.text: The very spring and root of honesty is good breeding.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Moralia, On the Education of Children ~100 CE

quotes.text: Painting is silent poetry, poetry is eloquent painting.
quotes.author: Plutarch
quotes.attribution: Moralia, On the Fame of the Athenians ~100 CE

quotes.text: Rest is the sauce of labor.
quotes.author: Plutarch

quotes.text: More people worship the rising than the setting sun.
quotes.author: Pompey

quotes.text: Stop quoting laws, we carry weapons!
quotes.author: Pompey

quotes.text: To sail is necessary, to live is not.
quotes.author: Pompey

quotes.text: Man is the measure of all things.
quotes.author: Protagoras

quotes.text: On gods, I cannot know if they exist.
quotes.author: Protagoras

quotes.text: A rolling stone gathers no moss.
quotes.author: Publilius Syrus

quotes.text: Anyone can hold the helm when the sea is calm.
quotes.author: Publilius Syrus

quotes.text: The fear of death is more to be dreaded than death itself.
quotes.author: Publilius Syrus

quotes.text: The opportunity is often lost by deliberating.
quotes.author: Publilius Syrus

quotes.text: What is most just? To sacrifice.
quotes.author: Pythagoras
quotes.attribution: Iamblichus,  On the Pythagorean Life 82 ~570 BCE

quotes.text: Enough eloquence, little wisdom.
quotes.author: Sallust

quotes.text: But all our power lies in both mind and body.
quotes.author: Sallust

quotes.text: For the glory of wealth and beauty is fleeting and perishable.
quotes.author: Sallust

quotes.text: But many mortals, dedicated to their belly and to sleep.
quotes.author: Sallust

quotes.text: But when sloth has usurped dominion, a false semblance of severity.
quotes.author: Sallust

quotes.text: Their heart grew cold.
quotes.author: Sappho

quotes.text: What cannot be said will be wept.
quotes.author: Sappho

quotes.text: Someone, I tell you, in another time will remember us.
quotes.author: Sappho

quotes.text: You burn me.
quotes.author: Sappho

quotes.text: The sun shines even on the wicked.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Life is long if you know how to use it.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: People are frugal in guarding their property, but wasteful of time.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: While we wait for life, life passes.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The greatest remedy for anger is delay.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Anger is a short madness.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Time discovers truth.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The best cure for anger is to wait.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Every night before sleep, review the day.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Revenge is the confession of pain.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Fire tests gold; adversity tests strong men.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Nothing is so bitter that a calm mind cannot find comfort.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Whatever can happen at any time can happen today.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Fate leads the willing, drags the unwilling.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Religion is regarded by the common as true, wise as false, rulers as useful.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Let nature be your teacher.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: We suffer more in imagination than reality.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Poverty with security is better than plenty in fear.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Philosophy is the medicine of the soul.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Freedom is won by living simply.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Shun luxury; it softens the spirit.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: To be everywhere is to be nowhere.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Philosophy teaches us to act, not to speak.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Wealth is the slave of a wise man, master of a fool.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: True happiness is to enjoy the present.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Enjoy present pleasures so as not to harm future ones.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: You must live for another if you wish to live for yourself.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Begin at once to live, and count each day as a life.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Cease to hope and you will cease to fear.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Nothing is burdensome if taken lightly.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It is better to conquer grief than to deceive it.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Associate with people who are likely to improve you.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Most powerful is he who has himself in his own power.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Let us say what we feel, not what we ought to say.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: As long as you live, keep learning how to live.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: No evil is great which is the last.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Death is a release from all pains.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Drunkenness is nothing but voluntary madness.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Every new beginning comes from some other beginning’s end.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The happy life is to have a sound mind in a sound body.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: No one is more hated than he who speaks the truth.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The point is not how long you live, but how nobly.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: We are members of one great body.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The mind that is anxious about the future is miserable.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: What need is there to weep over parts of life? The whole of it calls for tears.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Sometimes even to live is an act of courage.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: All cruelty springs from weakness.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The willing are led by destiny.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The unexamined life is not worth living.
quotes.author: Socrates

quotes.text: I know that I know nothing.
quotes.author: Socrates

quotes.text: Wonder is the beginning of wisdom.
quotes.author: Socrates

quotes.text: A lie never lives to be old.
quotes.author: Sophocles

quotes.text: No man loves life like him that's growing old.
quotes.author: Sophocles

quotes.text: A short saying often contains much wisdom.
quotes.author: Sophocles

quotes.text: How dreadful knowledge of the truth can be when there's no help in truth!
quotes.author: Sophocles

quotes.text: It is better not to live at all than to live disgraced.
quotes.author: Sophocles

quotes.text: A bad peace is even worse than war.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: Reason and judgment are the qualities of a leader.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: The more corrupt the state the more numerous the laws.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: Things forbidden have a secret charm.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: Crime, once exposed, has no refuge but in audacity.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: Men are more ready to repay an injury than a benefit.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: Greater things are believed of those who are absent.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: Prosperity tries the fortunate, adversity the great.
quotes.author: Tacitus

quotes.text: Lovers' quarrels are the renewal of love.
quotes.author: Terence
quotes.attribution: Andria, Act III, scene 3, line 23 (555) ~166 BCE

quotes.text: Hence these tears.
quotes.author: Terence

quotes.text: I am human, I consider nothing human alien to me.
quotes.author: Terence
quotes.attribution: Heauton Timorumenos, Act I, scene 1, line 25 (77) ~163 BCE

quotes.text: Nothing is so difficult but that it may be found out by seeking.
quotes.author: Terence
quotes.attribution: Heauton Timorumenos, Act IV, scene 2, line 8 (675) ~163 BCE

quotes.text: History is philosophy teaching by examples.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War ~400 BCE

quotes.text: We do not imitate, but are a model to others.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.10.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: It is a common mistake in going to war to begin at the wrong end.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.122.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The future is unknowable, but the past should guide us.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.22.4 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: In times of peace, sons bury their fathers; in war, fathers bury their sons.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.23.5 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Men are in a state of war not because they are armed, but because they are men.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.23.5 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The truest cause of war is the desire for more.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.23.6 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: We secure our friends not by accepting favors, but by doing them.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.32.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Men's minds are won by the good they receive rather than by the good they confer.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.42.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: War is not so much a matter of armaments as of expenditure.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.83.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: We must remember that one man is much the same as another.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 1.84.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Freedom is the sure possession of those alone who have the courage to defend it.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.37.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The secret of happiness is freedom, and the secret of freedom is courage.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.37.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Self-control is the chief element in self-respect.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.40.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Wealth to us is not mere material for vainglory but an opportunity for achievement.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.40.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Ignorance is bold, and knowledge reserved.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.40.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The bravest are surely those who have the clearest vision.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.40.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The doer of the favor is the firmer friend.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.40.4 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The whole earth is the tomb of famous men.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.43.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Men's indignation is spent on the present evil.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.59.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Men are swayed more by fear than by reverence.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.61.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Men naturally despise those who court them, but respect those who do not give way.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.61.4 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The tyranny that Athens imposed on others, it ultimately inflicted on itself.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.63.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Love of glory is the most common motive for great actions.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.64.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The greatest glory is to be had from the greatest dangers.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.64.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: It is frequently a misfortune to have very brilliant men in charge of affairs.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 2.65.10 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Few things are brought to a successful issue by impetuous desire.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 3.45.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Revolution thus ran its course from city to city.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 3.82.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The sufferings which revolution entailed were many and terrible.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 3.82.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Men are more eager to return evil than to remember good.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 3.82.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The cause of all these evils was the love of power.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 3.82.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The meaning of words had no longer the same relation to things.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 3.82.4 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Words had to change their ordinary meaning.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 3.82.4 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Most men prefer to be given a plausible lie than an unpalatable truth.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 4.108.4 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Men do not rest content with parrying the attacks of a superior.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 4.18.2 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Peace is an armistice in a war that is continuously going on.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 4.59.3 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Hope is an expensive commodity.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 5.103 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: Right, as the world goes, is only in question between equals in power.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 5.89 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The question is not of justice, but of power.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 5.89 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: The strong do what they can; the weak suffer what they must.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 5.89 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: In a democracy the poor will have more power than the rich.
quotes.author: Thucydides
quotes.attribution: History of the Peloponnesian War, 6.39.1 ~410 BCE

quotes.text: So little pains do the vulgar take in the investigation of truth.
quotes.author: Thucydides

quotes.text: Money has no odor.
quotes.author: Vespasian

quotes.text: Dear me, I must be turning into a god.
quotes.author: Vespasian

quotes.text: I sing of arms and the man.
quotes.author: Virgil

quotes.text: Perhaps it will be pleasant to remember these things one day.
quotes.author: Virgil

quotes.text: The one safety for the vanquished is to hope for none.
quotes.author: Virgil

quotes.text: I fear the Greeks even when they bring gifts.
quotes.author: Virgil

quotes.text: Accursed hunger for gold.
quotes.author: Virgil

quotes.text: Every one of you is the leader.
quotes.author: Xenophon

quotes.text: It is only for those to employ force who possess strength without judgment.
quotes.author: Xenophon

quotes.text: Conquerors do not, as a rule, give up their arms.
quotes.author: Xenophon

quotes.text: The thing is to get them to turn their thoughts to what they mean to do.
quotes.author: Xenophon

quotes.text: Yet is it more honorable... to treasure in the memory good acts than bad.
quotes.author: Xenophon

quotes.text: If the things that are are many, they must be both like and unlike.
quotes.author: Zeno of Elea
